definition:
Suppose that the series $\sum_{n=1}^\infty 1/n$ converged. Since all the
terms are positive, we could regroup them as we please, in particular,
split the series into two series, that of even terms and that of odd
terms: $$\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} {1 \over n} =
 \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} {1 \over 2n} +
 \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} {1 \over 2n-1}$$ Since
$\sum_{n=1}^\infty 1/n = 2 \sum_{n=1}^\infty 1/(2n)$, we would conclude
that $$\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} {1 \over 2n} =
 \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} {1 \over 2n-1} .$$ But $2n-1 < 2n$, hence
$1/(2n) < 1/(2n-1)$, so we would also have
$$\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} {1 \over 2n} <
 \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} {1 \over 2n-1} ,$$ which contradicts the previous
conclusion. Thus, the assumption that the series converged is untenable.
phrase: Proof Of Divergence Of Harmonic Series (By Splitting Odd And Even Terms)
